skills.name: Alphabet 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
##Reading back to front

Did you know that Arabic is written right to left?

|English letters | Arabic letters |
| -------- | --------- |
| d |  |
| aa |  |
| daa |   |

(See? Right to left! How cool is that?)

This means that when you pick up a book or magazine written in Arabic, you should start reading from the back cover  which, of course, is the front!

##Aah!!

When Arabic is written using English letters, sometimes therell be two vowels in a row.

|English letters | Arabic letters |
| -------- | --------- |
| daa |  |
| duu |  |
| dii |   |

This doesnt mean that there are two vowels in Arabic, but rather that there is one loooong vowel. Yes, Arabic has both short and long vowels! Youll be learning more about this soon.

##Oh, duh

When you see a tiny forward slash above a letter, it means this letter has a short ah sound right after it. Well talk more about this later.

|English letters | Arabic letters |
| -------- | --------- |
| d |  |
| da |  |

##Wow, yeah!

Sometimes  = **uu** (long vowel) and other times  = **w**. 

|English letters | Arabic letters |
| -------- | --------- |
| zuu |  |

**BUT**

|English letters | Arabic letters |
| -------- | --------- |
| zaw |   |
| wa |  |

Same with the letter : sometimes  = **ii** (long vowel) and sometimes  = **y**.

|English letters | Arabic letters |
| -------- | --------- |
| zii |  |

**BUT**

|English letters | Arabic letters |
| -------- | --------- |
| zay |   |
| ya |  |

The key is other vowels! If there is a vowel right before or right after   or , then they become w and y. Otherwise, theyre just the long vowels **uu** and **ii**.

skills.name: Alphabet 2
skills.tipsAndNotes:
##Mighty Morphing Power Letters

In English, letters can change shape, like if theyre uppercase or lowercase. Letters in Arabic, instead, change shape, based on where they are in comparison to other letters because they can connect to neighboring letters. Look at the shapes of  b:

| Position | Arabic letters | English letters |
| --- | ---- | ---- |
| Independent |  | b |
| Beginning of word |  | bar |
| Middle of word |  | jabar |
| End of word |  | rajab |


Letters can have up to four shapes, though some have fewer than that.

All letters have the independent form and the End of word form (which means connecting to the previous letter).

However, not all letters connect to the following letter   some letters don't have the beginning and middle of the word forms.

Note that the letter combinations you will see in the course to help you learn to read and write in Arabic do not necessarily have a meaning.


##  = dh

The new letter  (dhaal) makes the same sound as the letter combination th in the following English words: the, this, brother, bathing. In our transliteration system,  will be represented as **dh**. 

Note that this is **not** the same sound as th in the following set of English words: thick, thunder, broth, bath. This th sound corresponds to a different letter in Arabic that you will learn soon.

skills.name: Alphabet 3
skills.tipsAndNotes:
## In the beginning...

In the last skill, you learned to recognize some letters (like  and ) by themselves and at the beginning of a word. 

| English letters | Arabic letters |
| -- | -- |
| Bob |  |
| George |  |

Heres how  looks in other positions:

| Position | English letters | Arabic letters |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Middle | kabar |  |
| End | kab |  |

And heres how  looks:

| Position | English letters | Arabic letters |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Middle | kajad |  |
| End | kaj |  |

Exciting!


## Letters vs. words

Arabic has 28 letters and several smaller markings (like short vowels) and youll be learning all of them in this course! So you need lots of practice with letters at first.

Thats why youll go through several lessons on the alphabet and then youll get to one with new vocabulary. But dont worry, there will be more and more vocab as you progress in the course!

skills.name: Alphabet 4
skills.tipsAndNotes:
## The Beautiful Camel
Did you know that vowels in Arabic can be short or long, and that using the wrong one might change the meaning of the word? 

| Vowel length | Arabic letters | English letters | Meaning |
| --- | --- | --- | -- |
| Short |  | jamal | camel |
| Long |  | jamaal | beauty |

At first, itll probably be tricky for you to hear the difference between short and long vowels. Itll come with practice! 


## I Have House

Notice that there is no word in Arabic that means **a** or **an**.

| Word | Meaning |
| -- | -- |
|  | house / a house |
|  | jacket / a jacket |

This isnt the case for the word **the**, though...Well talk about **the** later.

## A door big

In English, when you want to describe a noun with an adjective (like a new jacket or a big door), you put the adjective (new, big) before the noun (jacket, door).

Have you noticed how its the opposite in Arabic?

| Phrase | Translation |
| -- | -- |
|   | a new jacket (literally: a jacket new) |
|   | a big door (literally: a door big) |

skills.name: Descriptions 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
## Hold it!

In Arabic, if you hold the sound of a consonant extra long, it might change the meaning of a word. We use a symbol called shadda (it looks like a small w) over a consonant to signal that its extra long. In English letters, well just write two of the same consonant. 

| Word | With English letters | Meaning | Word with shadda | With English letters | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- |
|  | daras | he studied |  | darras | he taught |
|  | Hamaam | pigeons |  | Hammaam | bathroom |

Note the shadda on the Arabic words on the right side, and the double rr and double mm in darras and Hammaam. When a letter has shadda on it, just hold it extra long!

## We saw chicken at the farm!

The word  (dajaaj) is a collective plural, meaning that it is a singular noun that refers to an entire group or category. 

In the context of food, it is best translated as chicken because English chicken also refers to an entire category of meat. However, in the context of a chicken coop,  is best translated as chickens because it refers to the entire group of chickens rather than a single chicken. 

Just remember:  is NOT a single chicken.

##What is number 3 doing here?
As we write Arabic words with English letters, the letter  has no equivalent. So to make it easier for you, we will use the number 3 that looks just like an inverted  to remind you when to use it. It is informal, but it helps.

skills.name: Descriptions 2
skills.tipsAndNotes:
**Duo amazing!**

Thats what youre literally saying in Arabic when you want to say Duo is amazing! 

That is because most of the time, the words **am**, **is** and **are** simply arent expressed in Arabic.

| Phrase | Translation |
| -- | -- |
|   | George is happy (literally: George happy) |
|    | Judy is from Juba (literally: Judy from Juba) |

This fun, right?

## La la la la la

Youre about to be introduced to the letter  (**l** in English) and learn its different shapes. One thing to remember is that when  is followed by  within the same word, the result is unexpected!

** +  = **

skills.name: Countries 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
## Uh-oh

You already know that the letter  makes a long *aaaaah* sound. But it can also do other things! 

For example, it can carry the tiny letter  . This letter (called hamza) is pronounced like the sound you make between uh and oh when you say, uh-oh! 

Words that sound like they start with a vowel in Arabic usually start with hamza first, then the vowel.

Notice that   can appear in different spots, depending on the vowel its written with.

###Above the 

| English letters | Arabic letters |
| -- | -- |
| 2a |  |
| 2u |  |

###Below the 

| English letters | Arabic letters |
| -- | -- |
| 2i |  |

## Whats the Deal With the 2?
In English, there is no letter that corresponds to  . Since  looks like a reversed 2, we write it in English letters using the number 2. Check out these examples from the course:

| English letters | Arabic letters |
| -- | -- |
| 2a |  |
| 2u |  |
| 2i |  |
| 2uu |  |
| 2ii |  |


We owe this innovation to the texting culture. Because the texting technology was originally based on the English alphabet, Arabic speakers got used to texting in Arabic using English letters. Since theres no good English letter equivalent of , they started using 2.

skills.name: Omar Is...
skills.tipsAndNotes:
## Th

Read these words out loud: 

| **th** version one | **th** version two |
| -- | -- |
| three | the |
| moth | mother |
| tooth | smooth |

Do you notice that the sound of **th** is different for the words on the left side than it is for the words on the right side? 

In Arabic, those two **th** sounds are actually different letters!

In the word  (siith) Seth, "th" is like the th in three. We will use **th** for the letter  when transliterating in English letters.

In the word  (dhakiyy) smart, "th" is like the th in the. We will use **dh** for the letter  when transliterating in English letters.

## Zero vowels

There is a marking in Arabic that tells you when there is no vowel. It looks like a tiny zero:

  = kabur
  = kabr

See the small zero there in kabr? Its telling you this word is pronounced kabr. Here are some other examples:

 = masak
 = mask

 = jabar
 = jabr


## This is at you! (aka you have got this)

In English, when you want to talk about things you have or possess, you just say **I have a pen.** In Arabic, you say this a little differently. 

| Arabic version | Literal translation | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- |
| .   | at Judy a house | Judy has a house. |
| .   | at Omar a garage | Omar has a garage. |

Be aware that "" is not a verb.

##Lebanon  Lebanese
To make the nationality adjectives, it is totally easy. For a singular masculine person, we just add the letter  to the end of the country's name. So  = Lebanon becomes  = Lebanese, and  = Oman becomes  = Omani. We will talk about the forms with other subjects later.

skills.name: Countries 2
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Youve already learned that when you see  /  at the beginning of a word, its just pronounced . The  stays silent. 

But what about when its in the middle or at the end of a word? You might see  either on the line or on top of other letters. Dont worry about learning the rules for which happens when  just know that these forms exist and learn how they sound.

skills.name: Phrases
skills.tipsAndNotes:
## -an

You already know that a tiny slash above a letter makes the sound **a**. But what if you see two tiny slashes at the end of a word? Well, that symbol makes a different sound: **an**. Usually, -an is written above , making it look like this: . (The  is silent!)

| Arabic word | With English letters | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- |
|  | shukran | thank you |
|  | SabaaHan | in the morning |
|  | masaa2an | in the evening |

Some people prefer to write -an first and then to add the silent alif, like this:  (instead of ). Either way, the word is pronounced the same way: shukran!


##  = 3

Today, youll hear a sound that we dont have in English:  !

Pronouncing  can be a bit tricky at first. Some people compare its sound to the sound you make when you yawn, some say its the sound you make when you hurt yourself and it hurts real bad  some even say it sounds like a duck. 

You can try this: get close to a mirror, open your mouth wide and fog up the mirror with your breath. You should feel how tight your throat gets when you do this. Now, while doing this, say the vowel a as in cat. Thats about the right sound. 

Because this letter, when its not connected to another letter, looks like a reversed 3, well write it as a **3** in English letters. For example, we write the word  as **3arabiyy**.


## Yaa dude!

In Arabic, you use the word  (yaa) before addressing someone. You can think of it as an attention getter, kind of like hey! but not as informal.

  !

Hello, Omar. 

  !

Thank you, Carrie.


## He is to she what 2anta is to 2anti

 In English, when youre talking about someone, you have to specify their gender with either he or she. In Arabic, you also specify gender when talking to someone directly. 

| Feminine | Masculine |
| -- | -- |
| 2anti  = you (female) | 2anta  = you (male) |
| hiyya  = she | huwwa  = he |

skills.name: Descriptions 3
skills.tipsAndNotes:
In Arabic, all nouns and adjectives are either masculine or feminine, even when they dont refer to people. Feminine nouns and adjectives usually end with the letter . This letter sounds like a short a and it can only be found at the end of words. 

If an adjective describes a noun, it has to agree with the noun: this means that if the noun is masculine, the adjective is masculine, but if the noun is feminine, then the adjective is feminine. 

| Masculine | Feminine |
| --- | --- |
|    = a smart translator (male) = mutarjim dhakiyy |   = a smart translator (female) = mutarjima dhakiyya  |
|    = an American professor (male) = 2ustaadh 2amriikiyy |   = an American professor (female) = 2ustaadha 2amriikiyya  |

skills.name: You and Me
skills.tipsAndNotes:
## ghhhhhh

Have you ever gargled? If so, you probably already know how to make the sound of the letter .  Put some water in your mouth, throw your head back and gargle away! Thats your Arabic homework.


In English, well write  as **gh**.

 = 

At the end of a word,  may appear in a different shape: . The two alifs ( and ) are not interchangeable, so youll need to memorize which is used where.

on, on top of = (3alaa)  

Standard Arabic = (al-3arabiyya l-fuSHaa)  

Great Britain = (bariiTaanyaa l-kubraa)   


## Yes or no?

Have you noticed that questions that start with a question word in English (what, who, why, how, when, etc.) cannot be answered by yes or no, while questions that start with a verb (are you, did we, can she, will they, has he, etc.) require an answer with yes or no? 

####Why did the duck cross the road?  

-Yes 

-No 

-To prove he wasnt a chicken! 


####Did Adam have a belly-button?

-Yes 

-No 

-At 3PM. 

-Because she was smart. 

-Through telepathic mind control. 

Well, in Arabic, yes/no questions begin with the word  (hal).  doesnt have a translation in English  it just means, hey, Im a yes/no question!  you ready for this?

skills.name: University
skills.tipsAndNotes:
## Ha!

Arabic has so many cool sounds! Like the , for example. This is the sound it makes when you get close to a window, open your mouth wide and fog up the window. Try it at home! 

Dont get this new sound mixed up with the other h ( / ), the one that sounds like the first letter in the word house in English. See if you can hear the difference between the two in todays exercises. And dont get discouraged if its tricky at first! Youll get there!

## The university is a girl??

Remember that when an adjective describes a noun, it has to match the gender of the noun   a masculine adjective with a masculine noun, and a feminine adjective with a feminine noun. This is true for all nouns, even those that dont refer to people!

| Masculine | Feminine |
| --- | ---- |
|   = an Arab country |   = an Arab city |
|   = a new house |   = a new university |

skills.name: Are You...?
skills.tipsAndNotes:
## My uncle is dear

Another cool, new Arabic sound is . To make this sound, you need to gargle with water but without the singing. Try to whisper as you gargle and you should be making the right sound. 

We write  as **kh** with English letters.

This is not the same as  (**gh**), which is the sound you make when you gargle normally, without whispering. 

expensive, dear = (ghaalii) 

my mothers brother = (khaalii) 



## The

To say **the house** instead of **a house** in Arabic, just put the two letters  (**al-**) in front of the word .

| a thing | the thing |
| -- | -- |
|  = a house |  = the house |
|  = a door |  = the door |
|  = a queen |  = the queen |

You can do this with any noun in Arabic!

skills.name: Family 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
## Mr. T

Ready for a cool new sound? Lets call it Mr. T. This is a bigger, stronger version of regular t. Its the sound of the letter   in Arabic and we write it as capital **T** in English letters. 

How does Mr. T sound different from regular t?

t + a = ta, close to standard American English tap

T + a = Ta, close to standard American English taco

Listen to the vowels  a vowel that comes after Mr. T sounds farther in the back of the mouth, while one that comes after t sounds closer to the front of the mouth. Some words may sound similar, but if one of them contains regular t and the other Mr. T, they are different words!

to repent = (taab) 

to be good, pleasant = (Taab) 


## Gender is complicated

Youve seen  at the end of all feminine nouns so far. However, there are a few nouns that look a little different! These include: 

mother = (2umm) 

sister = (2ukht) 

daughter / girl = (bint) 


## Oh my!

If you want to say something like This is my house in Arabic, you need to add an extra little ending onto the thing that is mine. 

| something | my something |
| -- | -- |
| house = (bayt)  | my house = (baytii)  |
| mother = (2umm)  | my mother = (2ummii)  |

You just add  at the end of the noun. Now its yours! Be careful, though  this only works for words that dont end in .

skills.name: What's Your Name?
skills.tipsAndNotes:
## q, not qu

Another distinct Arabic sound is . Its kind of like the sound k in English, except much deeper in the throat. Practice it and youll totally get it!

We write  as **q** with English letters.

Iraq = (al-3iraaq) 


## -ak and -ik

Remember how, in order to say **my house**  you just add  at the end of **house**? Well, to say **your house** or **your son** you add  (-ak) when talking to a man and  (-ik) when talking to a woman. 

son = (ibn) 

your son (to a man) = (ibnak) 

your son (to a woman) = (ibnik)

skills.name: Family 2
skills.tipsAndNotes:
## Mr. Ts little brothers

You already know the difference between regular t and Mr. T   the vowels around Mr. T sound tougher, more serious and grave than they do around regular t. There are actually three more pairs like  /  in Arabic. 

Another pair is  (**dh**) and  (**DH**) These two letters are similar, but the vowels around **DH** are further back in the mouth.

warner, herald = (nadhiir) 

equal = (naDHiir) 


##  <-  

If you want to say that a city is **my city** or **your city**, something funky happens. Remember,  (city) ends in . You make that   into  (-at) (!!), and then you add the my or your endings you already know. 

| Word | With English letters | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- |
|  | madiina | a city |
|  | madiinatii | my city |
|  | madiinatak | your city (to a male) |
|  | madiinatik | your city (to a female) |

This doesnt apply just to city but to all nouns that end in .

| Word | With English letters | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- |
|  | jaara | a (female) neighbor |
|  | jaaratii | my (female) neighbor |
|  | jaaratak | your (female) neighbor (to a male) |
|  | jaaratik | your (female) neighbor (to a female) |


## Whats whose?

As you know, each Arabic noun is either masculine or feminine, and adjectives have to match that gender. 

| Masculine noun | Feminine noun |
| -- | -- |
| The house is pretty = (al-bayt jamiil)   | The city is pretty = (al-madiina jamiila)   |

This gender never changes! Since  is masculine, it remains masculine, even if the person who owns it is a woman. The same is true for feminine nouns.

| Person being spoken to | Masculine noun | Feminine noun |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Male | Your house is pretty (to a male) = (baytak jamiil)   | Your city is pretty (to a male) = (madiinatak jamiila)   |
| Female | Your house is pretty (to a female) = (baytik jamiil)   | Your city is pretty (to a female) = (madiinatik jamiila)   |

A house will always be  and a city will always be , regardless of whose it is!

skills.name: Clothes 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
##  /  

The new letter  (Daad) is so important to the Arabic language that Arabs sometimes refer to themselves as   people of the Daad. We write it capital **D** with English letters.

 is the last of Mr. Ts little brothers. It makes the same sound as  except the vowels around  are more serious and grave. Here again, it will take practice to distinguish the two, but its important that you try!

| Arabic version | English version | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- |
|  | dall | to show, guide | 
|  | Dall | to stray |


## Mr. Ts family

Youve now met all of Mr. Ts relatives. Some resources refer to them as emphatics. Here they all are with their non-emphatic equivalents.

| Mr. T and relatives, Arabic version | Mr. T and relatives, English version | Regular letters, Arabic version | Regular letters, English version | 
| -- | -- | -- | -- |
|  | T |  | t |
|  | DH |  | dh |
|  | S |  | s |
|  | D |  | d |

Remember the letters in the left columns sound like those in the right columns except further back in the mouth.

## Have at you!

You probably remember that in order to say Judy has in Arabic, you use the word  at/to followed by Judy.

| Arabic version | Literal translation | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- |
| .   | at Judy a house | Judy has a house. |

What about I have and you have? Well, you also use . Instead of someones name, you add a short ending to   the same endings as when you say my house or your house.

| Arabic version | Literal translation | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- |
|  | house-my | my house |
| .  | at-me a house | I have a house. |
| -- | -- | -- |
|  | house-your | your house (to a man) |
| .  | at-you (male) a house | You have a house. (to a man) |
| -- | -- | -- |
|  | house-your | your house (to a woman) |
| .  | at-you (female) a house | You have a house. (to a woman) |


## I got nothin

To say do not have / does not have with the word you know for possession (), all you need to do is add the word  (laysa) in front of it! 


| have / has sentences | Translation | do not have / does not have sentences | Translation |
| -- | -- | -- | -- |
| .   | Judy has a house. | .    | Judy does not have a house. |
| .  | I have a dog. | .   | I do not have a dog. |
| .  | You have a scarf. (to a woman) | .   | You do not have a scarf. (to a woman) |



## The blue (wo)man (adjective) group

So far, every time youve seen an adjective describe a feminine noun, this adjective has ended with the letter .

  = a Syrian city 
  = a smart woman

But some adjectives (especially adjectives that describe color) take a different form in the feminine.  

| Masculine examples | Translation | Feminine examples | Translation | 
| -- | -- | -- | -- |
|   | a blue house |   | a blue city |
| .  | The house is blue. | .  | The city is blue. |

Its easiest to learn those special feminine adjectives together with the masculine: practice saying 2azraq / zarqaa2  /  and repeat it until youre blue in the face!

skills.name: At Home 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
##  /  

The new letter  (written capital **S** with English letters) is another of Mr. Ts little brothers. It contrasts with  in the same way  contrasts with  : mostly with vowel sounds that are further in the back of the mouth.

Sam = (saam) 

to fast = (Saam) 


## Sword or dagger?

One more alif! While regular alif looks more like a sword, dagger alif is a tiny vertical line that sits above a letter, more like a dagger. It only appears in a few really old words in Arabic and it sounds exactly like .

this (masculine) = (haadhaa) 

but, however = (laakinn) 

God = (allaah) 


## Sneaky Al

You know  means the. However,  you may have noticed its used differently in Arabic than the is in English. For example, look at these sentences:

This is a house = (haadhaa bayt)  

This is a city = (haadhihi madiina)  

BUT

this house = (haadha l-bayt)  

this city = (haadhihi l-madiina)  

The ONLY difference between this house and This is a house is  ! Sneaky, sneaky Al.

skills.name: In My Bag
skills.tipsAndNotes:
## There, there

The word  (hunaak) means both there and there is/there are. So how will you know the difference? Its easy: word order! When  comes first in a sentence, it means there is/there are.

|   = there is/are | Translation |  = there | Translation | 
| -- | -- | -- | -- |
| .  | There is a house. | .  | The house is there. |
| .   | There is a white scarf. | .  | The scarf is there. |



## There is no spoon

To say there is no or there are no, simply add the negator  in front of . 

| Sentences with there is/are | Translation | Sentences with there is no | Translation | 
| -- | -- | -- | -- |
| .  | There is a house. | .   | There is no house. |
| .   | There is a white scarf. | .    | There is no white scarf. |

skills.name: Office
skills.tipsAndNotes:
## House of Bob

In English, if Bob has a house, you call it Bobs house. 

**Possessor + s + what they possess**

In Arabic, a very common way to express the same thing is called iDaafa. In iDaafa, the order is reversed. 

**The thing they possess + possessor**


| English examples | Equivalent in Arabic | English letters |
| -- | -- | -- |
| Bobs house |   | bayt buub |
| Carries door |   | baab karii |
| the girls dog |   | kalb al-bint |
| the boys scarf |   | wishaaH al-walad |

If it helps, you can think of it as the house of Bob instead of Bobs house.

Notice how in Arabic, the thing that is possessed never ever gets  even if the meaning in English is the house or the dog. Its just the bare word!


## What the  ?!!

The letter  is a tricky one. First, it only ever shows up at the end of words. Second, you probably remember that it turns into  (-at) before my, your, etc. 

| Arabic examples | Pronunciation | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- |
|  | madiina | a city |
|  | madiinatii | my city |
| -- | -- | -- |
|  | jaami3a | a university |
|  | jaami3atak | your university (to a man) |


Here is something else that makes  tricky: when the first word of an iDaafa (aka the thing thats possessed) ends in , like in   the city of Bob or Bobs city, the spelling of  doesnt change but its pronunciation does. Instead of a, it is pronounced -at.

| Arabic examples | Pronunciation | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- |
|  | madiina | a city |
|   | madiinat buub | Bobs city |
| -- | -- | -- |
|  | jaami3a | a university |
|   | jaami3at karii | Carries university |
| -- | -- | -- |
|  | qiTTa | a cat |
|   | qiTTat al-walad | the boys cat |

As in all iDaafas, the first word cant have  the on it. Its just the bare noun.

skills.name: Describing a picture 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
## His and hers

You already know how to say my and your. But what about his or her? 

For his, just add (-hu)  at the end of the word. And for her, add (-haa)  instead. Its that simple.

| a (noun) | Pronunciation | Meaning | his (noun) | Pronunciation | Meaning | her (noun) | Pronunciation | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- |
|  | mi3Taf | a coat |  | mi3Tafhu | his coat |  | mi3Tafhaa | her coat |
|  | bayt | a house |  | baythu | his house |  | baythaa | her house |

Remember that if the noun ends with , it turns into  (-at) before my, your, his, her, etc.

| a (noun) | Pronunciation | Meaning | his (noun) | Pronunciation | Meaning | her (noun) | Pronunciation | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- |
|  | madiina | a city |  | madiinathu | his city |  | madiinathaa | her city |
|  | qubba3a | a hat |  | qubba3athu | his hat |  | qubba3athaa | her hat |

skills.name: Hobbies 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
## I do!

In English, we say  I write and you write and he writes and she writes. You always have to include I or we or he or she.

In Arabic, words like I, we, and you, are optional before verbs. Fortunately, the Arabic verb alone can usually tell you whos doing the action, because the verbs have a special form for (almost) each person. For example, the I form always starts with . 

| Arabic with English letters | Arabic verb | Meaning | 
| -- | -- | -- |
| 2uHibb |  | I like/I love |
| 2anaam |  | I sleep |
| 2abtasim |  | I smile |



## I dont!

To say I do not (do something), just add the short word (laa)  in front of the verb!

| I (do) | Meaning | I (do not) | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- | -- |
|  | I cook |   | I do not cook |
|  | I like |   | I do not like |



## Seeing is believing!

In English, we say things like:

I like talking.
Talking is my favorite.

In Arabic, you can replace talking in those examples with the word  (al-kalaam).  is a noun (for example, it begins with  the like a noun), but it feels verb-y. So we call it a verbal noun.



This isnt the talking like in the sentence Im talking. That gets translated differently. 

| Arabic version | Literal meaning | English translation |
| -- | -- | -- |
|  | I talk / I am talking | I talk / I am talking |
| -- | -- | -- |
|  . | I like the talking. | I like talking / I like to talk. |
|  . | I want the talking. | I want to talk. |
|  . | The talking is good. | Talking is good. |

Notice how the literal translation of  is **the** talking--this is because verbal nouns are always used with  the (or some other definite marker).
 

## Shoot for the moon

Lets review !

| Arabic a | Arabic with English letters | Meaning | Arabic the | Arabic with English letters | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- |
|  | bayt | a house |  | al-bayt | the house |
|  | muhandisa | an engineer |  | al-muhandisa | the engineer |
|  | qiTTa | a cat |  | al-qiTTa | the cat |
|  | kalb | a dog |  | al-kalb | the dog |

All these nouns start with letters called moon letters. Theres another letter group called sun letters. 

If a word starts with a sun letter and you add  the to it, two things happen: 1. You dont pronounce the  in , and 2. The first letter in the word after  gets held twice as long.

| Arabic a | Arabic with English letters | Meaning | Arabic the | Arabic with English letters | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- |
|  | zawja | a wife |  | az-zawja | the wife |
|  | sayyaara | a car |  | as-sayyaara | the car |
|  | duktuur | a doctor |  | ad-duktuur | the doctor |
|  | rajul | a man |  | ar-rajul | the man |

In Arabic, its written like what you would expect (). But with English letters, its not al-zawja but rather az-zawja. So instead of saying the l, you pronounce the z extra long.

Here is a list of all sun vs. moon letters:

| Moon letters | Sun letters |
| -- | -- |
|  |  |
|  |  |
|  |  |
|  |  |
|  |  |
|  |  |
|  |  |
|  |  |
|  |  |
|  |  |
|  |  |
|  |  |
|  |  |
|  |  |

skills.name: Weather 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
## The pretty the house

You already know how to say things like a pretty house or a Syrian girl.

| Arabic version | Arabic with English letters | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- |
|   | bayt jamiil | a pretty house |
|   | bint suuriyya | a Syrian girl |
|   | mutarjim mumtaaz | an amazing translator |
|   | jaami3a mashhuura | a famous university |


When a word has  the on it, the adjective that describes it also needs to start with .

| Arabic version | Arabic with English letters | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- |
|   | al-bayt al-jamiil | the pretty house |
|   | al-bint as-suuriyya | the Syrian girl |
|   | al-mutarjim al-mumtaaz | the amazing translator |
|   | al-jaami3a al-mashhuura | the famous university |


## What if I forget and say  ?

If you mean to say the pretty house   (al-bayt al-jamiil) but say   instead, the meaning changes.    = The house is pretty. Thats a full-fledged sentence!

| al- al- | With English letters | Meaning | al- - | With English letters | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- |
|   | al-bayt al-jamiil | the pretty house | .  | al-bayt jamiil. | The house is pretty. |
|   | al-bint as-suuriyya | the Syrian girl | .  | al-bint suuriyya. | The girl is Syrian. |
|   | al-mutarjim al-mumtaaz | the amazing translator | .  | al-mutarjim mumtaaz | The translator is amazing. |
|   | al-jaami3a al-mashhuura | the famous university | .  | al-jaami3a mashhuura. | The university is famous. |



## 2aa 2 furious

When  is followed by the long aaaaaa vowel (), it is spelled  --this is an alif with a small wave on top of it. We write it **2aa** in English letters.  can appear at the beginning and in the middle of a word.

For example, the word  (al-qur2aan) the Quran / the Koran contains a hamza followed by  , and so it is spelled .

skills.tipsAndNotes:
## And now, spelling

Youve already learned that  can appear on top of a few different letters. Specifically, it can appear on top of  , and .

| Letter with  | Regular letter |
| -- | -- |
|  |  | 
|  (Notice: no dots!) |  |
|  /  |  | 

At this point, you don't need to know the hamza spelling rules. Just know hamza can show up in different positions.

| Examples of words containing  | Arabic with English letters | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- |
|  | qaari2 | reader |
|  | ghaa2ib | absent |
|  | mas2uul | responsible |
|  | yabda2 | he begins |
|  | shay2 | thing |
|  | jaa2at | she came |



## Hes got nothin


You already  know that  means **I have** and / means **you have.** 

So what about **he has** or **she has**? Easy! For **he has,** just add (-hu)  at the end of , and for **she has,** add (-haa)  instead. 

To say **he does not have** and **she does not have,** use the word .

| has | Meaning | Arabic with English letters | does not have | Meaning | Arabic with English letters |
| -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- |
|  | he has | 3indhu |   | he does not have | laysa 3indhu | 
|  | she has | 3indhaa |   | she does not have | laysa 3indhaa |



## In Florida heavy rain.

You know how to make there is / there are sentences using the word :

| Arabic version | Arabic with English letters | Meaning | 
| -- | -- | -- |
|   . | hunaak maTar thaqiil | There is heavy rain. |
|    . | hunaak wishaaH fii shanTatii | There is a scarf in my bag. |
|     . | laysa hunaak lugha Sa3ba | There is no difficult language. |

You might also hear another way to say **there is / there are** in formal Arabic. This way uses  reversed word order. 

| Arabic version | Arabic with English letters | Literal meaning | Meaning | 
| -- | -- | -- | -- |
|   . | fii shanTatii wishaaH. | In my bag a scarf. | There is a scarf in my bag. |
|   . | 2amaamii rajul ghariib. | In front of me a weird man. | There is a weird man in front of me. |
|   . | fii l-khalfiyya bayt. | In the background a house. | There is a house in the background. |

skills.name: At Home 2
skills.tipsAndNotes:
## WaSl up?

Youve already seen hamza look like . This hamza doesnt change whether it comes right after a consonant or a vowel.

|  NOT preceded by vowel | With English letters | Meaning |  preceded by vowel | With English letters | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- |
|  .| muHammad 2ustaadhii | Mohamed is my professor. |  . | shaadii 2ustaadhii | Shadi is my professor. |
|  . | liz 2ummhu | Liz is his mother. |  . | mahaa 2ummhu | Maha is his mother. |


Some words start with  and a short vowel on it without a hamza (like  and ). When these words come right after a vowel, the short vowel on  is replaced by a new symbol called waSla. 

WaSla looks like this: . It simply means Hi! The alif under me is silent! Move on to the next letter please! 

|  NOT preceded by vowel | With English letters | Meaning |  preceded by vowel | With English letters | Meaning | 
| -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- |
|   | muHammad **al-mu3allim** | Mohamed the teacher |   | shaadii **l-mu3allim** | Shadi the teacher |
|   | liz **al-mutarjima** | Liz the translator |   | mahaa **l-mutarjima** | Maha the translator |
|  | **al-bayt** | the house |   | fii **l-bayt** | in the house |

WaSla basically blends the previous word to the word that starts with .

## Now you pronounce it, now you dont 

Sometimes,  the is preceded by a vowel (so it becomes ) and followed by a sun letter. 

For example, if you want to say in the car, you are putting together three pieces: 
 (fii) +  (al) +  (sayyaara)

The  of in turns   (al-) into  (l-).

The  of car is a sun letter. So the  in  isnt pronounced, and the  gets held for double the time.

The result is: 
 +  +  =   = fii s-sayyaara

This is NOT fii al-sayyaara, but fii s-sayyaara. The basically dissolves into the mix! No trace of  and no trace of  (although  is still there in writing).

skills.name: Zero to ten
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Numbers in Arabic are the only thing you have left to learn in order to be able to read anything written in Arabic!

Arabic numbers look different from English numbers, but both Arabic and English numbers are commonly used in Arabic. For example, at a traditional market, youre more likely to see Arabic numbers, but in a text message you could see either.

One interesting thing to notice is that the digits within a number in Arabic are actually written left to right! So number 10, which is made up of  (1) and then  (0), is spelled  (and NOT ; that would be 01). 

Isnt Arabic fun?!

skills.name: Geography 2
skills.tipsAndNotes:
## The structure of possession

You know that the iDaafa structure is commonly used to express possession. Remember, in an iDaafa: 
1. The thing that is possessed comes first, followed by the possessor; 
2. The thing that is possessed must be a bare noun (aka no  the in Arabic);
3. If the thing that is possessed ends in , the  is pronounced -at.

Here are some iDaafas youre already familiar with. 

| English examples | Equivalent in Arabic | Arabic with English letters |
| -- | -- | -- |
| Bobs house |   | bayt buub |
| Mohameds restaurant |   | maT3am muHammad |
| the engineers newspaper |   | SaHiifat al-muhandis |


IDaafa can also be used to express things other than possession, like the city of Detroit and the state of Texas. 

| English examples | Equivalent in Arabic | Arabic with English letters |
| -- | -- | -- |
| the city of Detroit |   | madiinat diitruuyt |
| the state of Texas |   | wilaayat taksaas |
| George Washington University |    | jaami3at juurj waashinTun |



##  ##

You probably remember that a tiny slash above a letter makes the sound **a** and two tiny slashes at the end of a word make the sound **an**. 

| Arabic word | With English letters | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- |
|  | shukran | thank you |
|  | SabaaHan | in the morning |
|  | masaa2an | in the evening |

There are also special markings for -in and -un!

| Words with -i or -u | With English letters | Words with -in or -un | With English letters |
| -- | -- | -- | -- |
|  | al-bayti |  | baytin |
|  | al-baytu |  | baytun |



##    ##


Lets review some present verbs! Remember, the I form always starts with .

| Arabic verbs | Arabic with English letters | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- |
|  | 2uHibb | I like / I love | 
|  | 2aftaH | I open |
|  | 2a3rif | I know |

Here are the forms when different people are doing the action:

| Arabic verb | Arabic with English letters | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- |
|  | 2uHibb | I like/love | 
|  | tuHibb | you like/love (to a male) |
|  | tuHibbiin | you like/love (to a female) |
|  | yuHibb | he likes/loves |
|  | tuHibb | she likes/loves |


| Arabic verb | Arabic with English letters | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- |
|  | 2anaam | I sleep |
|  |  tanaam | you sleep (to a male) |
|  | tanaamiin | you sleep (to a female) |
|  | yanaam | he sleeps |
|  | tanaam | she sleeps |


Note that, because all Arabic nouns are either masculine or feminine, the he and she forms can be used to refer to things that arent people. For example, city is feminine so it takes the she verb  (tanaam) in the example below.

This city does not sleep. = (haadhihi l-madiina laa tanaam)    .

skills.name: Introductions/greetings
skills.tipsAndNotes:
## Hello!

In English, if someone says, Whats up? to you, there are a few specific answers you can give. (Not much, Hey, whats up, Hows it going). Arabic has some of these question-and-answer formulas, too!


| Speaker 1 says: | Meaning | Speaker 2 responds: | Meaning | 
| -- | -- | -- | -- |
|   | Good morning (literally morning of good) |   | Good morning (literally morning of light) |
|   | Good evening (literally evening of good) |   | Good evening (literally evening of light) |
|   | Peace be upon you |   | And upon you be peace |

Knowing these formulas will let you show off your cultural and linguistic know-how.  

Note that while the greeting   (as-salaamu 3alaykum) peace be upon you is very common, it is usually associated with Islam. This means, for example, that a Christian will not normally use this greeting with another Christian.


## Letter names

In some contexts, like spelling or clarifying contrast between sounds, knowing the names of the Arabic letters may be useful to you. Below are those names, using our transliteration system. 

Note that the Arabic alphabet technically includes all but the last three letters listed in this table.

| Arabic letter | Name of the letter (transliterated) |
| -- | -- |

|  | baa2 |

skills.name: Jobs 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
##  or  ##

Arabic has two ways of asking what?

Use **** in questions that dont contain a verb. (Ignore the fact that the English translation has a verb in it  what matters is the Arabic!)

| Arabic with English letters | Arabic examples | English translation |
| -- | -- | -- |
| maa smak? |   | Whats your name? |
| maa ra2yik? |   | What do you think? (Literally: Whats your opinion?) |


Use **** in sentences that contain a verb.

| Arabic with English letters | Arabic examples | English translation |
| -- | -- | -- |
| maadhaa tuHibbiin? |   | What do you love / What would you like? |
| maadhaa 2adrus? |   | What do I study? |


Beware! In questions like What book? where in English you can replace what with which (= Which book?), Arabic doesnt use  nor . You will learn the word for this type of what soon.

skills.name: Time 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
## The twenty-fifth hour

In Standard Arabic, in order to say 2 oclock you say   the second hour, and in order to say 3 oclock you say   the third hour. This is true for all hours from 2 to 12. 

| Hours 2-12 in Arabic | Arabic with English letters | Literal meaning | English equivalent |
| -- | -- | -- | -- |
|   | as-saa3a ath-thaanya | the second hour | 2 oclock |
|   | as-saa3a ath-thaalitha | the third hour | 3 oclock |
|   | as-saa3a ar-raabi3a | the fourth hour | 4 oclock |
|   | as-saa3a al-khaamisa | the fifth hour | 5 oclock |
|   | as-saa3a as-saadisa | the sixth hour | 6 oclock |
|   | as-saa3a as-saabi3a | the seventh hour | 7 oclock |
|   | as-saa3a ath-thaamina | the eighth hour | 8 oclock |
|   | as-saa3a ath-taasi3a | the ninth hour | 9 oclock |
|   | as-saa3a al-3aashira | the tenth hour | 10 oclock |
|    | as-saa3a al-Haadya 3ashara | the eleventh hour | 11 oclock |
|    | as-saa3a ath-thaanya 3ashara | the twelfth hour | 12 oclock |



For 1 oclock though, youll just say   the hour one and NOT the first hour.

And note that you dont say AM and PM! Instead, you say in the morning, in the afternoon, in the evening, etc. So 2 PM would be     (literally the second hour after noon). 


## lastu who you think I am ##

You already know that usually, instead of saying something like I am from Lebanon, you say    (literally I from Lebanon). The am or are or is drops out.

How about if youre not from somewhere, or not a lawyer, or not something else? You simply use the word  [lastu]. 

I am not from Lebanon =     or just   

I am not sick =    or just  

I am not home =     or just   

I am not from here =     or just

skills.name: Hobbies 2
skills.tipsAndNotes:
## house - houses, mouse - ?

So far, you havent seen many plural nouns in Arabic, but this is about to change! Check out these singular-plural pairs youll learn in the next few lessons:

| Arabic with English letters | Arabic examples | English translation |
| -- | -- | -- |
| fiilm - 2aflaam |  -  | movie - movies |
| dars - duruus |  -  | lesson - lessons |
| risaala - rasaa2il |  -  | letter - letters |
| qariib - 2aqaarib |  -  | relative - relatives |
| Sadiiq - 2aSdiqaa2 |  -  | friend - friends |
| kitaab - kutub |  -  | book - books |
| lugha - lughaat |  -  | language - languages |

As you can see, each plural noun above looks a little different!  Now when you learn new words, youll learn the singular-plural pair together. 

Dont worry, though! Once you know more vocabulary, youll be able to start predicting the plural of new nouns with good accuracy.



## Intro to the root system

You know how in English some words that share a root also have a common meaning, like for example the root home in words like homey, homeless and homebound? Or the root myth in words like mythical, mythological and mythology? Arabic does sort of the same thing!

In English, we usually form new words by taking the base word (the root) and sticking something before or after it (like un- or -less or -ical). Arabic, though, takes letters and inserts them before, after and in between the consonants of the root. 

So, for example, if myth was an actual Arabic root M - Y - TH that had to do with myths, then you could probably find the following words in Arabic: MaaYiTH, MiYaaTHa, muMaaYaTHa, istaMYaTHa, muMtaYiTH, taMYiiTH, taMaaYuTH, yanMaYiTH, and many more. The meaning of all these words would have to do with myths! 

Arabic speakers are able to easily understand the root meaning of each word by listening to the consonants, even new words theyve never heard. Thats because the extra letters are not added randomly but follow specific patterns. Youll learn more about patterns later.

Now that you get the idea, here are some actual Arabic examples. Look at the singular-plural pairs below.


| Arabic with English letters | Arabic examples | English translation |
| -- | -- | -- |
| DaRS - DuRuuS |  -  | lesson - lessons |
| RiSaaLa - RaSaa2iL |  -  | letter - letters |
| QaRiiB - 2aQaaRiB |  -  | relative - relatives |


The root of the word  (DaRS) lesson is the sequence  -  -   D-R-S. The meaning of this root is connected to studying. This same root appears in the same order in the plural  (DuRuuS) lessons but also in other words, like the verb  (yaDRuS) he studies or the noun  (maDRaSa) school (literally, the place of study). 

Try to identify the root of words you already know and see if you can start making connections between words that share the same root!


## The writing of letters

You already know that to say She likes writing, youd say   tuHibb al-kitaaba. The word  means writing.  

But what if you dont just like writing, but writing letters? Or reading a book? In order to say this, use an iDaafa construction with the verbal noun (e.g.   etc.) as the first term. Just as a reminder: iDaafa is the structure thats commonly used to express possession and it follows the following guidelines:

1. The thing that is possessed comes first, followed by the possessor; 
2. The thing that is possessed must be a bare noun (aka no  the in Arabic);
3. If the thing that is possessed ends in , the  is pronounced -at.

Here are some examples of verbal nouns first on their own (writing) and then in iDaafa construction (writing letters). 

| English sentence | Arabic equivalent | Arabic with English letters | Literal translation of the Arabic | 
| -- | -- | -- | -- |
| Writing is fun. |  . | **al-kitaaba** mumti3a | The writing is fun. |
| Writing letters is fun. |   . | **kitaabat** ar-rasaa2il mumti3a | Writing of the letters is fun. |
| -- | -- | -- | -- |
| I like reading. |  . | 2uHibb **al-qiraa2a** | I like the reading. |
| I like reading books. |   . | 2uHibb **qiraa2at** al-kutub | I like reading of the books. |

skills.name: Food 2
skills.tipsAndNotes:
## al- and food

Youve noticed that the use of  (al-) in Arabic and the in English doesnt always match up. Here are some examples of how to use  when discussing food. 


When discussing specific food items (i.e. the chicken from yesterday, the coffee you made, the salt thats on the table, etc.), use . This is similar to English.

I like the chicken from yesterday. =    . (2uHibb **ad-dajaaj** min 2ams)


The trickier part is when you want to discuss categories of food in general (i.e. chicken, bread, coffee, etc.). In this case, the use of  is mostly determined by the verb you choose.


**LIKE**

If you like a food in general, use .

I like chicken. =  . (2uHibb **ad-dajaaj**)

I like coffee. =   . (2uHibb **al-qawha**)


**WANT**

If you want a type of food in general, do not use . 

I want chicken. =   (2uriid **dajaajan**)

I want coffee. =   (2uriid **qahwa**)


**EAT/DRINK**

If you are discussing eating or drinking a type of food in general, using  on food items is optional. If you use it, youll sound more formal than if you dont.

I eat chicken.  =   (2aakul **dajaajan**) OR   (2aakul **ad-dajaaj**)

I drink coffee every morning. =     (2ashrab **qahwa** kull SabaaH) OR     (2ashrab **al-qahwa** kull SabaaH)



## dajaajan?

Look at this example sentence.

I want chicken. =   (2uriid **dajaajan**)

Do you wonder why the word  chicken ends with  -an in this sentence? Thats because chicken doesnt take the or my, your, etc. AND it is the object of a verb (I want what? I want chicken!). 

 is used to mark indefinite direct objects. Here are more examples. 

I want a friend. =   (2uriid **Sadiiqan**)

I eat bread. =   (2aakul **khubzan**)

I want a new house. =    (2uriid **baytan jadiidan**)

Note that any adjective that accompanies a noun ending in  also needs to end in  (baytan jadiidan a new house).

Remember that if a noun ends in , **   ** just sits on the  directly without an alif seat. In this case, **   ** -an is typically not written even though technically its there.

I want coffee. =   (2uriid **qahwa**) OR   (2uriid **qahwatan**)

skills.tipsAndNotes:
##     ##


Time to review some present verbs! Remember, the I form always starts with . Below are the forms when different people are doing the action (including, for the first time, some plurals).

| Arabic verbs | Arabic with English letters | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- |
|  | 2uHibb | I like/love | 
|  | tuHibb | you like/love (to a male) |
|  | tuHibbiin | you like/love (to a female) |
|  | yuHibb | he likes/loves |
|  | tuHibb | she likes/loves |
|  | nuHibb | we like/love |
|  | tuHibbuun | you all like/love |
|  | yuHibbuun | they like/love |


| Arabic verb | Arabic with English letters | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- |
|  | 2anaam | I sleep |
|  |  tanaam | you sleep (to a male) |
|  | tanaamiin | you sleep (to a female) |
|  | yanaam | he sleeps |
|  | tanaam | she sleeps |
|  |  nanaam | we sleep |
|  | tanaamuun | you all sleep |
|  | yanaamuun | they sleep |


## What which?

Today, youll learn the Arabic word that corresponds to which in questions like which book are you reading?

This word comes in two forms:  is masculine and  is feminine. To decide which one to use, simply match the gender of the noun that follows it. 

| Arabic | Arabic with English letters | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- |
|   | 2ayy kitaab | Which book? |
|   | 2ayy rajul | Which man? |
|   | 2ayy bayt | Which house? |
| -- | -- | -- |
|   | 2ayya wilaaya | Which state? |
|   | 2ayya mushkila | Which problem? |
|   | 2ayya khaala | Which maternal aunt? |

Colloquial English uses what and which interchangeably in sentences like what/which book are you reading? Dont let that confuse you! If you can replace what with which in English, then  /  is the word you want in Arabic.

skills.name: Food 3
skills.tipsAndNotes:
## Who are you calling weak?!

Most words in Arabic are based on a 3-consonant root. When  (y) or  (w) is the last consonant in the root of a verb, this verb is called weak, which means that it looks a little different when you put endings on it. The new verb  yashtarii he buys is based on the weak root  -  -   SH - R - Y. Pay attention to what happens to the final  in the present tense below. 

| Arabic verb | Arabic with English letters | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- |
|  | a2ashtarii | I buy |
|  |  tashtarii | you buy (to a male) |
| **** | **tashtariin** | you buy (to a female) |
|  | yashtarii | he buys |
|  | tashtarii | she buys |
|  |  nashtarii | we buy |
| **** | **tashtaruun** | you all buy |
| **** | **yashtaruun** | they buy |

See what happens with you (to a female), you all and they? The final  of the verb gets eaten by the endings  and  ! 



## Because I said so.

To say because in Arabic, use the word  (li2anna). A couple of things to know about :

First,  must be followed by a complete sentence, such as because humans are weird, because war sucks, because cartoons saved my life. 

Second, the word directly following  must be the subject of the sentence.

| Sentence without because | Meaning in English | Sentence with because | Meaning in English |
| -- | -- | -- | -- |
|  . | The world is weird. |   . | Because the world is weird. |
|   . | My sister studies a lot. |    . | Because my sister studies a lot. |

Note that subject pronouns (i.e. I, you, he, she, etc.) combine with  in the following way:
 +  =  "because I"
 +  =  "because you (male)"
 +  =  "because you (female)"
 +  =  "because he/it"
 +  =  "because she/it"

| Sentence without because | Meaning in English | Sentence with because | Meaning in English |
| -- | -- | -- | -- |
|   .| I am from Egypt. |   . | Because I am from Egypt. |
|  . | You are my mother. |  . | Because you are my mother. |
|   . | She is an amazing teacher. |   . | Because she is an amazing teacher. |
|  . | He is happy. |  . | Because he is happy. |




## 2 + 2 = 3

The short word  li- (to, for) in Arabic cant stand on its own; instead, it needs to be attached to the following word in writing. 

| Example in Arabic | Arabic with English letters | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- |
|  | li-2abii | to/for my father |
|   | li-haadhihi l-2ustaadha | to/for this professor |
|  | li-bayruut | to/for Beirut |

When the word following  starts with  al- (the), the alif in  disappears both in pronunciation and writing, just like this:  +  = 

| Example in Arabic | Arabic with English letters | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- |
|  | li-l-bint | to/for the girl |
|  | li-l-2ustaadha | to/for the professor |
|  | li-l-qaahira | to/for Cairo |

## Carrots, tomatoes, squash

A while back, you learned that the word  dajaaj is grammatically singular but can have a plural meaning. For instance, if you saw dajaaj at the farm, then you saw **chickens** rather than a single chicken. 

English also has nouns like that. Take furniture, for example. Youd say, Our furniture IS really nice (as opposed to are), even though furniture doesnt refer to one item but rather to a bunch of things (desks, tables, chairs, couch, etc.). 

Youre about to learn more of those nouns in Arabic -- carrots  jazar, tomatoes  banaduura, and squash  kuusaa are all singular in Arabic but they refer to a group of items.

skills.name: Phone 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
## I will drink

Good news! Expressing the future in Arabic is really easy: just add  sa- at the beginning of a present verb. Below is the verb to drink in the present and future tense, and you can do this with any verb!

| Present verb | Arabic with English letters | Meaning | Future verb | Arabic with English letters | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- |
|  | a2ashrab | I drink |  | sa-2ashrab | I will drink | 
|  | tashrab | you drink (to a male) |  | sa-tashrab | you will drink (to a male) |
|  | tashrabiin | you drink (to a female) |  | sa-tashrabiin | you will drink (to a female) |
|  | yashrab | he drinks |  | sa-yashrab | he will drink |
|  | tashrab | she drinks |  | sa-tashrab | she will drink |
|  | nashrab | we drink |  | sa-nashrab | we will drink |
|  | tashrabuun | you all drink |  | sa-tashrabuun | you all will drink |
|  | yashrabuun | they drink |  | sa-yashrabuun | they will drink |


## With or without you

Words like  (with),  (in, at),  (from),  (from, off), etc. combine with words like me, you, her, etc. so they become a single word in Arabic. Here is how  with combines with other words:

| Example in Arabic | Arabic with English letters | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- |
|  | ma3ii | with me |
|  | ma3ak | with you (to a male) |
|  | ma3ik | with you (to a female) |
|  | ma3ahu | with him |
|  | ma3ahaa | with her |

skills.name: Family 3
skills.tipsAndNotes:
## I love it!

You already know how to say I love my daughter and My cat eats all my food, but what about I love **her** and My cat eats **it**? Below are some ways to say this! 

| Example in Arabic | Arabic with English letters | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- |
|  | yuHibb-nii | he likes/loves me |
|  | ta3rif-nii | you know me |
| -- | -- | -- |
|  | a2uHibb-ak | I like/love you (to a male) |
|  | ta3rif-ak | she knows you (to a female) |
| -- | -- | -- |
|  | yuHibb-ik | he likes/loves you (to a female) |
|  | na3rif-ik | we know you (to a female) |
| -- | -- | -- |
|  | a2uHibb-hu | I like/love him |
|  | a2aakulhu | I eat it |
| -- | -- | -- |
|  | yuHibb-haa | he likes/loves her |
|  | nashrab-haa | we drink it |

Notice that these words like her and it attach to the end of the verb!


## whose brother?

The word  a2akh (brother) changes depending on what role its playing in the sentence. 

| Example in Arabic | Arabic with English letters | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- |
| .  | huwwa 2akh | He is a brother. |
| .   | huwwa 2akhuu muHammad | He is Mohameds brother. |
| .   | a2akhuu muHammad mumti3 | Mohameds brother is fun. |

 is only used if the word brother is the first word in an iDaafa, i.e. the brother of John, the brother of the teacher, the brother of Maryam, etc. or even your brother, her brother, etc. In every other case, the basic form  is used. 

| Example in Arabic | Arabic with English letters | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- |
|     | a2akhuu juun ya3mal kathiiran | The brother of John/Johns brother works a lot. |
|    | a3umar a2akhuu juun | Omar is the brother of John/Johns brother. |

skills.name: Hotel 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
## Our, their and everywhere

You already know how to say my, your, his and her. Now you will learn the plural forms: our, your (to more than one person) and their. Here are all the forms you know so far, attached to the noun  bayt (house).

| my house, your house, etc. | Pronunciation | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- |
|  | bayt | house |
|  | bayt-ii | my house |
|  | bayt-ak | your house (to a man) |
|  | bayt-ik | your house (to a woman) |
|  | bayt-hu | his house |
|  | bayt-haa | her house |
|  | bayt-naa | our house |
|  | bayt-kum | your house (to more than one person) |
|  | bayt-hum | their house |

Remember that if the noun ends with , it turns into  (-at) before my, your, his, her, etc. Below are all the forms you know so far, attached to the noun  jaami3a (university) which ends in .

| my university, your university, etc. | Pronunciation | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- |
|  | jaami3a | university |
|  | jaami3at-ii | my university |
|  | jaami3at-ak | your university (to a man) |
|  | jaami3at-ik | your university (to a woman) |
|  | jaami3at-hu | his university |
|  | jaami3at-haa | her university |
|  | jaami3at-naa | our university |
|  | jaami3at-kum | your university (to more than one person) |
|  | jaami3at-hum | their university |

In very formal Arabic, -kum  (your)  and -hum  (their) are used only for groups of at least three people including at least one man. But in slightly less formal, spoken Arabic, -kum  (your) and -hum  (their) can be used for any group of two or more people.


## Everybody has!

The same endings used to say our, your (plural) and their are also used on  to express we have, yall have and they have.

To say we/yall/they do not have, just use the word .

| Arabic version | Literal translation | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- |
|   | at-me a car | I have a car. | 
|    | not at-me a car | I do not have a car. |
| -- | -- | -- |
|   | at-you a car | You have a car. (to a man) | 
|    | not at-you a car | You do not have a car. (to a man) |
| -- | -- | -- |
|   | at-you a car | You have a car. (to a woman) | 
|    | not at-you a car | You do not have a car. (to a woman) |
| -- | -- | -- |
|   | at-him a car | He has a car. | 
|    | not at-him a car | He does not have a car. |
| -- | -- | -- |
|   | at-her a car | She has a car. | 
|    | not at-her a car | She does not have a car. |
| -- | -- | -- |
|   | at-us a car | We have a car. | 
|    | not at-us a car | We do not have a car. |
| -- | -- | -- |
|   | at-you a car | You have a car. (to more than one person) | 
|    | not at-you a car | You do not have a car. (to more than one person) |
| -- | -- | -- |
|   | at-them a car | They have a car. | 
|    | not at-them a car | They do not have a car. |

In more formal Arabic, the feminine  is used if the thing you dont have is feminine, e.g.    vs.   . But in slightly less formal, spoken Arabic,  can be used regardless of what is not possessed.

skills.name: Doctor 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
## Whos ? ##

The new word  is a big deal in Arabic.  is used much like English to in sentences like we want TO talk, and like English that in sentences like I hope THAT you sleep in. 

You may remember that Arabic words like  talking and  writing are called verbal nouns. Well,  introduces a verb clause in place of a verbal noun. So in order to say we want to talk, you can either say  **** nuriid al-kalaam or  ** ** nuriid 2an natakallam. 

Here are more examples of sentences in two versions: one with the verbal noun and one with .

| English sentence | Version 1 (verbal noun) | Version 1 with English letters | Version 2 () | Version 2 with English letters |
| -- | -- | -- | -- | -- |
| I like to sleep. |  **** | 2uHibb an-nawm |  ** ** | 2uHibb 2an 2anaam |
| You must talk with him. |  ****  | yajib al-kalaam ma3ahu |  ** **  | yajib 2an tatakallam ma3ahu |
| We can eat now. |   ****  | min al-mumkin al-2akl al-2aan |   ** **  | min al-mumkin 2an na2kul al-2aan |


## But which present?

As you see from the examples above, what follows  is a verb in the present. But this is a special present! Pay attention to sleep in Arabic in the following examples:


| Arabic example | Example with English letters | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- |
|   **** | yajib 2an **2anaam** | I must sleep. | 
|   **** | yajib 2an **tanaam** | You must sleep. (to a man) / She must sleep. |
|   **** | yajib 2an **tanaamii* | You must sleep. (to a woman) |
|   **** | yajib 2an **yanaam** | He must sleep. |
|   **** | yajib 2an **nanaam** | We must sleep. |
|   **** | yajib 2an **tanaamuu** | You all must sleep.|
|   **** | yajib 2an **yanaamuu** | They must sleep. |


For I, you (to a man), he, she and we, this new present looks the same as the present you already know. But for you (to a woman), yall and they, it looks different: the  at the end of the verb drops out, and a **silent** alif  appears instead **for yall and they only**. 


| Present you already know | With English letters | Meaning | New present | With English letters | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- |
| **** | **tanamiin** | You sleep. (to a woman) | **   ** | min al-mumkin 2an **tanaamii* | You can sleep. (to a woman) | 
| **** | **tanamuun** | Yall sleep. | **   ** | min al-mumkin 2an **tanaamuu* | You all can sleep. | 
| **** | **yanamuun** | They sleep. | **   ** | min al-mumkin 2an **yanaamuu* | They can sleep. | 


## Hand is a girl?!

By now, youve noticed that singular nouns that end in  are usually feminine, while those that dont are usually masculine. 

But some feminine nouns dont end in ! Some common ones are things that usually come in pairs in the human body, like eye, hand and foot.

| a _____ | In Arabic | With English letters | a big ______ | In Arabic | With English letters | 
| -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- |
| an eye |  | 3ayn | a big eye |   | 3ayn kabiira | 
| a hand |  | yad | a big hand |   | yad kabiira | 
| a foot |  | rijl | a big foot |   | rijl kabiira | 

See how big is in the feminine in the examples above? Thats because eye, hand and foot are feminine nouns, even though they dont end in !


## Do this, do that!

Over the next few lessons, youll start seeing different verbs in the command form, like open your mouth! or give me some carrots! For now, its best if you just learn a few of those verbs one at a time without worrying too much about how they are formed. 

One thing youll notice right away is that, regardless of the verb, when youre addressing a woman, the verb ends in  -ii and when youre addressing a group of people, the verb ends in  -uu (the alif is silent, just like it is after ). 

| In English | To a man | With English letters | To a woman | With English letters | To a group | With English letters |
| -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- |
| Open your mouth | ****  | iftaH famak | ****  | iftaHii famik | ****  | iftaHuu famkum |
| Come | **** | ta3aala | **** | ta3aalii | **** | ta3aaluu |

skills.name: Market 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
##Here you go, come in, go ahead. 3 in 1 ?!
The verb  expresses all these meanings. This arises form an Arabic cultural concept of honoring your guest. It literally means "please do me a favor and come in/take this thing/ pass ahead of me". Isn't it nice?

skills.name: Jobs 2
skills.tipsAndNotes:
## To be or not to be

You know that in order to say She is an engineer, you just say   (literally, she engineer). 

However, when you want to say something that happened in the past like I was tired or something that will happen like I will be there, you dont drop the was or will be. You also   use  yakuun, meaning to be, after . 

| Arabic example | Example with English letters | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- |
|   ****  /  | 2uriid 2an 2akuun muhandisan / muhandisa | I want to be an engineer. | 
|   ****  | turiid 2an takuun muhandisan | You want to be an engineer. (to a man) |
|   ****  | turiidiin 2an takuunii muhandisa | You want to be an engineer. (to a woman) |
|   ****  | yuriid 2an yakuun muhandisan | He wants to be an engineer. |
|   ****  | turiid 2an takuun muhandisa | She wants to be an engineer. |
|   ****  | nuriid 2an nakuun muhandisiin | We want to be engineers. |
|   ****  | turiiduun 2an takuunuu muhandisiin | You all want to be engineers. |
|   ****  | yuriiduun 2an yakuunuu muhandisiin | They want to be engineers. |

After this new verb to be, the thing you want to be ends in  -an (as long as that thing doesnt end in  and doesnt have the or my, your, his, etc. on it.)




## Easy. . . easier!

You may remember that most words in Arabic are based on a 3-consonant root, like  -  -   D - R - S in  yaDRuS he studies. Lets practice finding  the root of the following adjectives. 

| Adjective in Arabic | Root | Adjective in English |
| -- | -- | -- |
|  |  -  -  | difficult |
|   |  -  -   | easy | 
|   |  -  -   | big | 
|   |  -  -   | small | 
|   |  -  -   | old |
|   |  -  -   | new | 
|   |  -  -   | expensive |
|   |  -  -   | cheap |
|   |  -  -   | rich | 
|   |  -  -   | poor | 



Now that we have those roots, we can make comparisons, like more difficult or cheaper. To do that, you just plug the root in the following three blanks: 2a **_** **_** a **_** 

So if the root is  -  -   K - B - R (like in ), you will end up with: 2a **K** **B** a **R** = 

Lets try it with all the same adjectives as above!


| Comparative with English letters | Comparative in Arabic (2a _ _ a _) | Meaning |  Root  |
| -- | -- | -- | -- |
| 2aS3ab |  | more difficult |   -  -   |
| 2ashal |  | easier |  -  -  |
| 2akbar |  | bigger |  -  -  |
| 2aSghar |  | smaller |  -  -  |
| 2aqdam |  | older |  -  -  |
| 2ajadd |  | newer |  -  -  |
| 2aghlaa |  | more expensive |  -  -  |
| 2arkhaS |  | cheaper |  -  -  |
| 2aghnaa |  | richer |  -  -  |
| 2afqar |  | poorer |  -  -  |


Some interesting comparatives above are:

 (and not ) for adjective  -- thats what happens when the second and third consonants of the root are the same letter (in this case J - D - D)!

 more expensive (2aghlaa) and  richer (2aghnaa) where the combination short a + final ii = aa (and NOT ay)




## Nothings easier than this!

To say easier **than** or poorer **than**, just use the word  min. 

    (maHmoud 2afqar min saam) Mahmoud is poorer than Sam

    (ghassaan 2aghnaa min 3umar) Ghassan is richer than Omar

## Almost too easy

One nice thing about making comparisons in Arabic is that the comparative stays the same whether youre talking about a man, a woman or a group of people. 

| Comparison in Arabic | With English letters | Meaning | 
| -- | -- | -- |
|     | maHmoud 2akbar min raanyaa | Mahmoud is older than Rania. |
|     | raanyaa 2akbar min bashiir | Rania is older than Bashir. |
| -- | -- | -- |
|     | 2ummii 2aghnaa min 2abii | My mother is richer than my father. |
|     | 2abii 2afqar min 2ummii | My father is poorer than my mother. |


## In other news

The word other in Arabic is  in the masculine. Beware: the feminine doesnt take  but rather follows a different pattern: . 

| Examples in Arabic | With English letters | Meaning | 
| -- | -- | -- |
|    | yawm mumTir 2aakhar | another rainy day |
|   | rajul 2aakhar | another man |
|  | al-2aakhar | the Other / the other one |
| -- | -- | -- |
|   | marra 2ukhraa | another time, again |
|   | imra2a 2ukhraa | another woman |
|  | al-2ukhraa | the other one |

skills.name: Clothes 2
skills.tipsAndNotes:
## Your pant is nice!

Some nouns that are plural in English are singular in Arabic, like pants and shoes. This means those nouns take singular agreement, as illustrated by the examples below. 


| Examples in Arabic | With English letters | Meaning | 
| -- | -- | -- |
|    | haadha l-binTaal jamiil | These pants are pretty. |
|     | 2uriid al-Hidhaa2 al-2azraq al-jadiid | I want the new blue shoes. |

Do you notice the singular masculine agreement with all words that describe pants and shoes in the table above? Thats how it works! If its easier, you can think of these words are a pair of pants and a pair of shoes.


## cars, houses, books = she

You know that if you want to describe a masculine noun, you use a masculine adjective/verb/pronoun, etc. And if the noun is feminine, the agreement is feminine. 

| Examples of agreement with nouns | With English letters | Meaning | 
| -- | -- | -- |
|  ****. | al-maktab kabiir | The office is big. |
|  ****. | al-jaami3a kabiira | The university is big. |
| -- | -- | -- |
| ****   **** | haadhaa l-bayt laa yanaam | This house does not sleep. |
| ****   **** | haadhihi l-madiina laa tanaam | This city does not sleep. |
| -- | -- | -- |
| !****   ****  | haadhaa l-binTaal? na3am 2uHibbhu kathiiran | This pair of pants? Yes, I like it a lot! |
| !****   ****  | haadhihi S-SaHiifa? na3am 2uHibbhaa kathiiran | This newspaper? Yes, I like it a lot! |


One thing we havent seen yet is how to describe plural nouns. Arabic treats **non-human plurals** (e.g. cars, books, lessons, etc.) and **human plurals** (e.g. people, teachers, Arabs, Americans, etc.) differently. Today well learn how to deal with non-human plurals. 

Formal Arabic tends to view non-human plurals as one set, as opposed to a bunch of individual items. For this reason, it considers non-human plurals as **singular.** Non-human plurals take feminine singular agreement. This means that in order to describe non-human plurals, you will use words like  (they),  (these),  (them), etc.

| Examples of agreement with non-human plural nouns | With English letters | Meaning | 
| -- | -- | -- |
|  **** | ad-duruus sahla | The lessons are easy. |
| ****  **** ****  | haadhihi l-lughaat laysat Sa3ba 2abadan | These languages are not difficult at all. |
| -- | -- | -- |
|  **** | 2aflaamhu tusaa3idnii | His movies help me. |
| ****   ****  | haadhihi l-kutub? na3am 2uHibbhaa kathiiran | These books? Yes, I like them a lot. |

skills.name: Trip 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
## I wont cry, I wooont cryyy 

To say I will go, you know to add  in front of the present verb  I go. The result is  sa-2adhhab I will go.

But what about I will NOT go or we will NOT eat or they will NOT speak etc.? To say this, use the word  lan followed by the verb, i.e.   lan 2adhhab I will not go.

The table below contrasts will and will not.

| Will | Arabic with English letters | Meaning | Will not | Arabic with English letters | Meaning |
| -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- |
|  | sa-2ashrab | I will drink |   | lan 2ashrab | I will not drink | 
|  | sa-tashrab | you will drink (to a male) |   | lan tashrab | you will not drink (to a male) |
| **** | **sa-tashrabiin** | you will drink (to a female) | ** ** | lan **tashrabii** | you will not drink (to a female) |
|  | sa-yashrab | he will drink |   | lan yashrab | he will not drink |
|  | sa-tashrab | she will drink |   | lan tashrab | she will not drink |
|  | sa-nashrab | we will drink |   | lan nashrab | we will not drink |
| **** | **sa-tashrabuun** | you all will drink | ** ** | lan **tashrabuu** | you all will not drink |
| **** | **sa-yashrabuun** | they will drink | ** ** | lan **yashrabuu** | they will not drink |

As you see in the examples above, the present verb after  takes some special forms: the  drops out at the end of the verb for you (to a woman), you all and they, AND a silent alif is added at the end of the verb for you all and they only. This is just like the verb after !
